data.text: Panniers on the Front or Back Rack for Shortish Trips?
If you only require two panniers for a shortish trip do you carry them on the front or back ?
Depends, where you're going. If you do hill climbing put them in the front, if you're in flat terrain, put them in the back
data.author: Jeanette Mey

data.text: What's the difference?
data.author: Mark Wallis

data.text: the weight in the back feels like dragging you backwards when trying to go uphill
data.author: Jeanette Mey

data.text: Ah that's only one's perception, in reality there's no difference as we're pedalling the same mass, although after spoke issues on my third extended tour (due to a bad wheel build) I started to maximise the front load to balance the wheels load out, as the riders weight is predominantly on the the rear wheel.
data.author: Mark Wallis

data.text: I would prefer the rear, as the impact on the handling of the bike is smaller.
data.author: Heiko auf Touren

data.text: Even on a long trip I don‚Äôt carry panniers on the front. I carry two gravel panniers on the rear rack. If a long trip I have a medium size Ortlieb dry bag on top of these. I have a too tube bag, small cockpit bag and handle bar bag. I have water bottle cages on both sides of the fork and three on the frame. I travel as light as possible.
data.author: Richard Brass

data.text: On the back as it better for steering
data.author: Allan Galloway

data.text: Middle.
data.author: Fin Madden

data.text: Yes. Front or back.
data.author: Peter Lehman

data.text: Front, l if you have a low-trail bike...
data.author: Barry Kwaaitaal

data.text: Back, I never carry panniers on the front. I don't carry so much that I need front panniers, just a handlebar bag.
data.author: Gary Palmer

data.text: I love my front panniers. The bike handles really well. I have back too and distribute my weight based on the anticipated Ride. I try to keep 40% of the weight in the front.
data.author: Marcy Kelley

data.text: That's what I'm thinking ,I'm pretty heavy & I thought it would make more sense .
data.author: Kevin Dean

data.text: Depends on the frame geometry. Some bikes handle better with them on the front, others the rear.
data.author: Surplus Pete

data.text: Back. Too much on the front unbalanced and you could fly over the handlebars in a sudden stop, especially going downhill.
data.author: Ron Wechsler

data.text: I did a weekend trip with front panniers only, it was great, very well balanced.
data.author: Curtis Evans

data.text: Front. Always. All those commenting should disclose if they have actually ever toured with both rear only and front only‚Ä¶.
data.author: Craig Pullen

data.text: I'm not a fast rider & currently over 15 at ,I finding front helps with steep hills especially .
data.author: Kevin Dean

data.text: Back
data.author: Dean Derek

data.text: Back. Two panniers can get you across the country for three months with the right gear.
data.author: Ty Dawley

data.text: By the way: most rear wheel are weaker due to their derailleur ü§ì

data.text: Backpack on the handle bar: 10kg including tent, mattress 0¬∞ sleeping bag, 500g bread, warm / extra clothes
data.author: Georges Froidevaux

data.text: been looking for something like this. All the cables in front of the handle bar makes it a challenge though. Can I ask you about how you managed this? Is it a custom made front rack?
data.author: Anders Hansen

data.text: there is no rack. It‚Äôs about fixing the backpack to the upper tube or to the back of the stem. You can use the shoulder straps on the handle bar to prevent the bag to fall. I guess every setup (bike, backpack) needs own tuning and trial and error üçÄ
data.author: Georges Froidevaux

data.text: aha. I understand. Thanks
data.author: Anders Hansen

data.text: In all cases, the weights are carried on the back baskets. What if there is an extra weight it will be. In the front baskets and be lighter.
data.author: ŸÜÿ≤ÿßÿ± ŸÉÿßÿ∏ŸÖ ÿßŸÑŸÜŸàÿßÿ®

data.text: Back always...but then I have a hybrid. On the tandem, it would be the back but we generally go with front and back to stow stuff for 2
data.author: David Botterill

data.text: Usually back. Front panniers make the steering less responsive which is okay on low trail bikes (including dedicated touring bikes). Not so good on high trail bikes like mountain bikes or many bikepacking bikes. The Specialized AWOL was designed to preferentially use front panniers, but that is unusual.
data.author: David Backhouse

data.text: If you are maybe needing more space like to carry extra water and food, use the front panniers too.
data.author: Rachel Hugens

data.text: Each bike and tour is different. I rode with front only when I used a seat post bikepacking bag, frame bag, and handlebar backpacking bag. Front was too heavy. Handling was challenging, slower, and nor very reactive. A little move or shake of the hands and the front wheel and fork would swing left and right for a bit before it equalized again. You get used to it though. Before my current longer tour, (8 months) that required 4 panniers because I got a new camera with a few lenses, I went on a few short tours while I waited. I just used the 2 new rear panniers I just bought. I liked having all the weight on the back much more. I now ride with 4 panniers with the front ones being lighter and balanced in weight (left and right weight about the same). Rear panniers are heavier and one is at leave 5kg more than the other but on the back it's unnoticeable for balance For me, it's how it should be. For you, only you will know after you try. You are your own expert. The rest of us are just opinions regardless how strong or adamant they come off :)
data.author: Adir Sharon

data.text: Is this a serious question? Is it even possible to put all the weight in the front and nothing in the rear? Never heard or seen that.
data.author: Vladimir Gamlitsky

data.text: I know of lots of riders who only use front panniers
data.author: Phil Kneen

data.text: Back always!
data.author: Greg Morath

data.text: Rear
data.author: Jeff Stone

data.text: The rider's weight is mostly on the back wheel so putting them on the front balances out the load better. The front wheel is also stronger because it's not dished as much. Having the weight on the front takes some getting used to but it really helps with handling once you adjust. It will help keep the front wheel on the ground on steep hills too
data.author: Jacob Ashton

data.text: That's what I'm thinking.
data.author: Kevin Dean

data.text: Of course in back, The more weight in front, the more difficult it is to control.

data.text: I use front only as long as they are low rider‚Ä¶ otherwise on back‚Ä¶ though to be honest I‚Äôd still use 4 and spread the weight around.. I take exactly the same stuff on a short tour as I do for a longer tour‚Ä¶. If you have packed something you don‚Äôt need for 3 days then you don‚Äôt need it at all‚Ä¶
data.author: Daryn Dobson-Bailey

data.text: I always have my panniers at the front, no matter what the load.
data.author: Phil Kneen
